headline: Nvidia, AppLovin, Molson Coors Beverage: Trending Tickers
summary: Nvidia (NVDA) stock rises after the US Commerce Department said it will not enforce global artificial intelligence (AI) chip curbs, though China chip restrictions remain in effect. AppLovin (APP) stock surges on news that the company will sell its gaming unit to Tripledot Studios for $400 million and 20% of its stock. Molson Coors Beverage Company (TAP) lowers its outlook for the full year, sending the stock lower in premarket trading. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief here.

headline: Molson Coors (NYSE:TAP) Reports Sales Below Analyst Estimates In Q1 Earnings
summary: Beer company Molson Coors (NYSE:TAP) missed Wall Street’s revenue expectations in Q1 CY2025, with sales falling 11.3% year on year to $2.30 billion. Its non-GAAP profit of $0.50 per share was 37.2% below analysts’ consensus estimates.

headline: Molson Coors cuts forecasts as beer demand hurt by tariff-led recession worries
summary: (Reuters) -Molson Coors cut its annual forecasts for sales and profit on Thursday, in anticipation of a hit to demand for its Coors and Miller beer brands as consumers cut back discretionary spending due to tariff-led recession worries.  The company, which is in search of a new CEO, also missed market expectations for its first-quarter results, sending its shares down about 8% in early trading.  U.S. consumers have been paring back on discretionary spending such as alcohol amid elevated prices, with flip-flops in U.S. trade policy stoking recession worries.

raw.headline: Molson Coors cuts forecasts as beer demand hurt by tariff-led recession worries
raw.summary: (Reuters) -Molson Coors cut its annual forecasts for sales and profit on Thursday, in anticipation of a hit to demand for its Coors and Miller beer brands as consumers cut back discretionary spending due to tariff-led recession worries.  The company, which is in search of a new CEO, also missed market expectations for its first-quarter results, sending its shares down about 8% in early trading.  U.S. consumers have been paring back on discretionary spending such as alcohol amid elevated prices, with flip-flops in U.S. trade policy stoking recession worries.
